coredata.dc:title: Seamless alloying stabilizes solid-electrolyte interphase for highly reversible lithium metal anode
coredata.dc:creator: Jiang, Yunpeng

coredata.dc:description: Despite their widespread study, lithium metal anodes still face the bottleneck problem of low average Coulombic efficiency. Herein, we adopt an electroless plating method and introduce additive (vanillin) to develop nanoscale silver hosts. The uniform nanoscale silver layer is conducive to seamless Li/Ag alloying process, thereby enabling flat lithium deposition. Since the Li/Ag alloying process occurs after the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), the seamless alloying process stabilizes the SEI, which improves the reversibility of the lithium metal anode. On this basis, a 3D-printed copper host-coated dense nanoscale silver layer is constructed, which reduces the effective current density and hence lowers the polarization of lithium deposition or stripping. Moreover, the 3D structure induces the epitaxial growth of lithium and thus alleviates the volume change of lithium metal. As a result, an average Coulombic efficiency of 99.61% is achieved in the Li/3D Ag half-cell.

seamless alloying
stabilizes SEI
epitaxial growth

(A) Phase diagram of Li/Ag alloying process.
(B) Schematic diagram of constructing 2D Ag host and 3D Ag host.
Optimized Ag host and physical properties
(A–E) SEM images of each host.
(F) Calculation of the adsorption energy between Cu/Ag and vanillin and the Tafel curves of electroless Ag plating.
(G) XRD spectrum; the insets are the optical diagrams of Cu foil and Ag foil.
(H) EDX mapping images of Ag-0.1 host.
Morphology and schematic diagram of the Li deposition
(A–E) SEM images after deposited 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal.
(F–H) Schematic diagram of Li deposition on various hosts: (F) Cu foil; (G) uneven Ag foil; and (H) uniform Ag foil.
Mechanism between Li/Ag alloying process and SEI formation
(A) Curves of the first Li deposition at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 0.01 mA cm−2.
(B) First enlargement based on curves of 0.1 mA cm−2.
(C) Second enlargement based on curves of 0.01 mA cm−2.
(D) CV curves of Cu foil and Ag foil.
Simulation of Ag hosts and physical and chemical properties
(A) COMSOL simulation of Li/Ag alloying process.
(B) Schematic diagram of Li/Ag alloying process: seamless alloying process shows a flat surface, and the stress of Li deposition on the natural SEI is evenly distributed.
(C) Cycling curves of Ag foil and Cu foil based on symmetric cells.
(D) Schematic diagram of constructing 3D Ag host.
(E and F) SEM images (E) and EDX mapping images (F) of 3D Ag host.
(G) COMSOL simulation of 3D Ag host.
(H) SEM images after deposited 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal on 3D Ag host.
Electrochemical performance of half-cells and full cells
(A) CE for half-cells that are composed of various hosts and Li foil.
(B) Comparison of average CE for half-cell with recent research.
(C and D) SEM images after 50 cycles of half-cell: (C) 3D Cu host and (D) 3D Ag host.
(E and F) Full cells adopt LiFePO4 as cathode and the hosts after Li deposition as anode: (E) cycling curves at 1C and (F) capacity-voltage curve at different rates.

head.ce:title: Seamless alloying stabilizes solid-electrolyte interphase for highly reversible lithium metal anode

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Despite their widespread study, lithium metal anodes still face the bottleneck problem of low average Coulombic efficiency. Herein, we adopt an electroless plating method and introduce additive (vanillin) to develop nanoscale silver hosts. The uniform nanoscale silver layer is conducive to seamless Li/Ag alloying process, thereby enabling flat lithium deposition. Since the Li/Ag alloying process occurs after the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), the seamless alloying process stabilizes the SEI, which improves the reversibility of the lithium metal anode. On this basis, a 3D-printed copper host-coated dense nanoscale silver layer is constructed, which reduces the effective current density and hence lowers the polarization of lithium deposition or stripping. Moreover, the 3D structure induces the epitaxial growth of lithium and thus alleviates the volume change of lithium metal. As a result, an average Coulombic efficiency of 99.61% is achieved in the Li/3D Ag half-cell.

Jiang et al. adopt vanillin as additive for electroless silver plating to construct a silver-modified layer on a 3D-printed host, which induces continuous and lateral lithium deposition. Uniform and seamless lithium deposition after the formation of SEI promotes uniform stress distribution and avoids multi-interface SEI, thus indirectly stabilizing the natural SEI.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: All the necessary data supporting the main findings of the paper are available within the main paper and its supplemental information files and from the lead contact upon reasonable request.

ce:section.ce:para:
As the anode of Li batteries, Li metal anode has attracted much attention, owing to its lowest potential among the alkali metals (−3.04 V versus the standard hydrogen electrode) and high specific capacity (3,860 mAh g−1 or 2,061 mAh cm−3). 1–3 However, the wide application of Li metal anode has been largely jeopardized by the safety issues essentially caused by Li dendrites. 4–7 For the last several years, much research work has been devoted to understanding the mechanisms of Li dendrite formation, and several approaches of suppressing Li dendrite formation have been proposed. 8–13 On the basis of these understandings, various strategies have been attempted to alleviate the Li dendrite problem, for example, including structural hosts restricting volume variation, 14–16 lithophilic matrixes inducing uniform Li deposition or stripping, 17–21 artificial solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) stabilizing the interface, 22–26 electrolyte additives regulating the whole system, 27–32 solid-state electrolytes improving safety and energy density, 33–38 separator modifications indirectly regulating Li deposition or stripping, 39–42 and so on. Although Li dendrite formation can be effectively suppressed, the low Coulombic efficiency (CE) of Li stripping and deposition still limits the application of Li metal anodes. The common reasons of the low CE are (1) uneven Li deposition and infinite volume change lead to the fracture of natural SEI and new SEI re-formed at the crack consumes electrolyte and active Li metal, thereby reducing the reversibility of Li deposition or stripping and (2) the protuberance present on the SEI rupture possesses a higher local electric field, favoring further Li deposition on it, which eventually evolves into Li dendrites. Moreover, the dendrites can be easily broken during the Li stripping (isolated Li), forming "dead" Li and dead SEI, further reducing the reversibility of Li deposition or stripping. 43
,
44 The long-term vicious circles lead to two undesirable consequences: (1) the dendrites pierce the separator and cause short circuit and (2) the depletion of active Li metal and electrolyte causes the instantaneous increase in polarization. However, there is a further cause of the low CE that has been largely neglected. Uniformly distributed but discontinuous Li deposition leads to the formation of multiple SEI films, which consume additional electrolyte and active Li metal, reducing the reversibility of Li deposition or stripping.

Although the Li deposition or stripping can be stable up to over 500 cycles 45 and 800 cycles, 46 it is still not good enough for a long-term application based on the low average CE (<99.9%). Assuming that the Li metal anode possesses a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 and the Li deposition or stripping is at an average CE of 99.0%, 1.0% of active Li metal (0.01 mAh cm−2) would be consumed in each cycle. When Li deposition or stripping reaches 100 cycles, 1 mAh cm−2 of the active Li metal will be completely depleted. By an analogy, an average CE of 98.0% leads to the loss of 1 mAh cm−2 active Li metal in only 50 cycles. Therefore, it is very important to improve the average CE of Li metal anodes. For practically valuable applications, Li metal anodes shall exhibit an average CE >99.9% in order to meet the matching requirements of the booming commercial cathodes, 44 such as LiFePO4, 47
,
48 LiNixCoyAl1-x-yO2, 49
,
50 and LiNixCoyMn1-x-yO2. 51
,
52 However, CE >99.9% only exists in a few individual cycles. 53–55 It has been a big challenge to achieve average CE >99.9% at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2 for long-term cycles.

To the best of our knowledge, the state of the art of average CE is 99.5% at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2, 56
,
57 which could maintain 1 mAh cm−2 active Li metal cycling for 200 cycles. Solution-based Li/Ag alloying phase in Ag-modified host has been proven to induce uniform Li nucleation and effectively improve the reversibility of Li deposition or stripping (average CE is 98.0%–99.5% at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2). 14
,
46
,
57 Nevertheless, randomly distributed Ag particles in the current modified hosts lead to discontinuous Li/Ag alloying process, which promotes regional Li deposition, resulting in the formation of multiple SEI films, thereby consuming additional active Li metal and electrolyte. Thus, the improvement of average CE of Li stripping and deposition is still limited.

To achieve highly reversible Li metal anode, herein, we construct a uniform and dense nanoscale Ag layer on the Cu substrate by electroless plating, which achieves a seamless Li/Ag alloying process and promotes coherent Li deposition, thereby indirectly stabilizing the SEI (average CE ∼99.61% at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2). Ag matrix is selected as the host, where the Li/Ag alloying process promotes the nucleation overpotential of Li deposition close to zero, which facilitates reversible Li deposition or stripping. 58 In order to obtain a uniform nanoscale Ag-modified layer, we purposely introduce an additive (vanillin) into the plating solution to control the electroless Ag plating. Vanillin is chosen as the additive because it is proven to adsorb on the protrusions of the deposited Zn and increase the overpotential for further Zn plating, resulting in a flat Zn surface. 59–61 Interestingly, the dense Ag layer is beneficial to induce solid-solution Li/Ag alloying process (Figure 1A) and almost seamless Li deposition, which means that less SEI is formed on the Li metal, effectively alleviating the consumption of multiple SEI films. In addition, we find that alloying process does not participate in the formation of SEI but occurs after SEI. Moreover, the flat Li/Ag alloying process produces a uniform stress distribution on the SEI, which in turn stabilizes the SEI. With these understandings, we construct a 3D-printed Cu host-coated dense nanoscale Ag layer, which not only alleviates the volume change but also induces the epitaxial growth of Li deposition, further improving the reversibility of Li deposition or stripping. Finally, the 3D Ag host and Li foil are combined to assemble into a half-cell, which achieves an average CE ∼99.61% at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2. In addition, LiFePO4 and 3D Ag pre-deposited Li metal are assembled into a full battery, giving rise to a capacity retention rate >85% after 500 cycles. Such a strategy of seamless alloying process can be extended to other alloying hosts (such as Li/Sn, 62–64 Li/Mg, 65
,
66 Li/Sb, 67
,
68 Li/Zn, 69
,
70 et al.), thereby promoting the actual application of alloying process on Li metal anode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fabrication of the nanoscale Ag hosts
ce:section.ce:para: Nanoscale Ag-modified layer was constructed on Cu foil by electroless plating. Vanillin was introduced as an additive to regulate the electroless plating behavior, thereby achieving the uniform and dense Ag deposition. On this basis, the electroless Ag plating process was grafted onto 3D-printed Cu to prepare the 3D Ag host (Figure 1B). As expected, the electroless plating strategy is environmentally friendly, and the plating solution can be recycled. Furthermore, 3D printing is also suitable for industrialized production.

With Cu foil, the concentration of additive (vanillin) was adjusted to optimize the morphology of electroless plating, thus achieving a uniform and dense Ag-modified layer. The surface of a conventional Cu foil is shown in Figure 2A, and the dispersive Ag protrusions appeared after electroless plating without additive (Figure 2B). With the introduction of additive (0.01 M vanillin, simplified as Ag-0.01), the Ag protrusions became smaller, which was less than 50 nm (Figure 2C). On this basis, the concentration of additives was further increased (0.1 M vanillin, simplified as Ag-0.1) and the Ag-modified layer was smooth and free of protrusions (Figure 2D). Nevertheless, scattered Ag protrusions appeared again (Figures 2E and S1) when the concentration of the additive reached 0.3 M (simplified as Ag-0.3) and 0.5 M (simplified as Ag-0.5).

In the Tafel curves, the left (high potential) represents Cu oxidation and the right (low potential) represents Ag reduction. According to the analysis of Tafel curves (Figure 2F), the reduction potential of Ag plating increased with the increase in additive and the potential polarization of Ag-0.1 plating was the largest. However, the polarization potential of Ag-0.3 plating became smaller. This is because the excess additive was also adsorbed on the Cu surface, which inhibited the Cu oxidation and promoted the positive shift of the Cu oxidation potential (Figure S2). Therefore, the equilibrium potential of the Cu/Ag conjugation reaction was shifted positively, which made the equilibrium potential of Ag plating exhibit a "polarization decrease" phenomenon. When the concentration of the additive was increased to 0.5 M, the polarization potential was close to 0.3 M (indicating that the additive had been adsorbed to saturation). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses, based on the Ag (111) and Cu (111) crystal planes (Figure 2G), in combination with the density functional theory (DFT) of calculating the adsorption energy between the additive (vanillin) and the above two crystal planes, suggested that the adsorption energy of the additive with Ag (−3.06 eV) was stronger than that of Cu (−2.09 eV). Therefore, the vanillin would have preferentially adsorbed on the Ag surface and increased the polarization of the continued Ag deposition, while the Ag turned to deposit on the Cu surface, thereby achieving uniform Ag deposition. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) further proves that Ag element on the surface of Ag-0.1 was uniformly distributed (Figure 2H). Furthermore, the cross-section scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the Ag-0.1 host show that the thickness of the Ag layer is about 400 nm (Figure S3A).

Li deposition or stripping behavior was investigated in 2025-coin cells, using Ag foil or Cu foil as the working electrode and Li foil as the counter or reference electrode. At a current density of 1 mA cm−2, 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal was deposited on each host. It can be clearly seen that the Cu foil is covered with Li dendrites (Figure 3A), which consumes a large amount of active Li metal and electrolyte to form SEI (Figure 3F). Although Ag foil can effectively suppress dendrites, as a result of the Li/Ag alloying, the Ag nanoparticles lead to rather localized bulk Li deposition (Figure 3B) and the formation of SEI boundaries (Figure 3G). With the uniform and dense distribution of Ag nanoparticles, the SEI boundaries of Li deposition gradually decrease (Figures 3C and 3E). Interestingly, Ag-0.1 host shows seamless Li/Ag alloying due to the rather uniform and dense Ag-modified layer (Figure 3D), with less SEI on the surface (Figure 3H). Therefore, the reaction between the active Li metal and the electrolyte is effectively reduced, thereby improving the reversibility of the Li metal anode. Moreover, the cross-section SEM image of Ag-0.1 host after depositing 1 mAh cm−2 Li metal exhibits continuous Li deposition, which is ∼5-μm thickness (Figure S3B).

With the gradual stripping of Li metal (charged to 1.0 V), Li dendrites on the Cu foil become slender and not completely peeled off, forming a porous electrode, which is not conducive for subsequent cycles. Although the Ag hosts (Ag, Ag-0.01, and Ag-0.3) have effectively inhibited the formation of dendrites, the dispersive Ag distribution induces agglomerated Li deposition, which ultimately leads to the residue of randomly distributed skeletons, which means that the active Li metal and electrolyte are consumed to form extra SEI. However, the Ag-0.1 host exhibits uniform Li stripping due to coherent Li/Ag alloying process and a relative flat surface (Figure S4).

In order to clarify the high reversibility of the Ag-0.1 host, the coin half-cells were used to investigate the cyclic stability of the Li deposition or stripping. Among all tested hosts (Cu foil, Ag, Ag-0.01, Ag-0.1, Ag-0.3, and Ag-0.5), Ag-0.1 shows the best cycling stability at 20 °C (Figure S5). In addition, the charge and discharge voltage curve shows that the Li nucleation overpotential of Ag-0.1 host tends to zero at 0.1 mA cm−2, and the polarization potential of Li deposition or stripping at 1 mA cm−2 is smaller than that of Cu host (Figure S6). Therefore, one can conclude that the Ag-0.1 host has the best overall performance, and subsequent studies are all carried out using Ag-0.1, referred to as Ag.

Based on the above analysis, some interesting questions can be raised. What is the relationship between Li/Ag alloying process and SEI formation? Which process happens first? Or is it accompanied? With the above questions, we conducted further analysis. The first Li deposition (discharge) was performed on Cu host and the Ag host at a conventional current density (0.1 mA cm−2). Except for the Li deposition platform below 0 V, there are only three platforms above 0 V (Figure 4A), and the platform potentials are all less than 0.1 V in the first enlargement (Figure 4B). However, the other platforms are clearly visible when the current density of the first Li deposition is reduced to 0.01 mA cm−2 (Figure 4A). Interestingly, similar voltage plateaus above 0.1 V appeared for Cu and Ag hosts, which can be in association with the formation of SEI. What is more, the Ag host in the second enlargement (Figure 4C) still has the same three platforms as the first enlargement, which may well be in connection with the occurrence of Li/Ag alloying.

To further verify the above two considerations in regard to SEI formation and Li/Ag alloying process, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) surface inspection was adopted to analyze the composition of each voltage platform, thus verifying whether alloying process is involved in the formation of SEI (Figure S7). When the first discharge reaches 1.2 and 0.6 V, the elements in the SEI can be detected on the surfaces of Cu host and the Ag host, and there are obvious peaks of Cu and Ag elements. In the early stage of Li deposition, SEI was so thin that XPS could not detect the elements of the host. As the Li deposition progresses (discharge continues to 0.3 V), the peaks of Cu and Ag elements weaken. Upon nucleation and continuous deposition, elements in the host would not be effectively detected on its surfaces, suggesting that Li/Ag alloying process did not participate in the formation of SEI but occurred after SEI. Moreover, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the half-cell also show that, in the first Li deposition platform, SEI is formed above 0.1 V and the process of Li/Ag alloying process below 0.1 V (Figure 4D). Furthermore, the platform with SEI being formed is basically stable after the second cycle (Figures S8 and S9). The above results are consistent with the analysis of the previous Li deposition curves. Therefore, it can be concluded that SEI has formed before alloying process.

According to the above analysis, COMSOL modeling was adopted to simulate the effect of different Li-deposited behavior on SEI. On the Cu host, uneven Li deposition induces Li protrusions and the SEI at the protrusions is broken, causing current accumulation and consuming active Li metal and electrolyte to re-form SEI, and the apical dominance based on the SEI rupture further leads to the formation of Li dendrites (Figure S10). However, the initial Li/Ag alloying would be uniformly dispersed and the surface would become flat, which means that the SEI is stable. Moreover, the current is concentrated in the unalloyed sites, filling the pores and achieving seamless Li/Ag alloying process (Figure 5A). Based on these analyses, one can speculate that coherent Li/Ag alloying gives rise to a smooth interface and uniform stress distribution, thereby stabilizing SEI (Figure 5B). Therefore, the flat surface eliminates SEI cracks induced by uneven protrusions, avoids the formation of new SEI, effectively reduces the consumption of active Li metal and electrolyte, and facilitates the subsequent uniform Li deposition or stripping, realizing highly reversible Li metal circulation.

On this basis, 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal was electrodeposited on the hosts and assembled into symmetrical batteries to test the cycling stability of Li deposition or stripping. Under the condition of 20 °C, the voltage hysteresis of Li deposition or stripping on the Ag host was at 20 mV at 0.5 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2, and the symmetrical battery was cycled with stability for ∼1,800 h (Figure 5C). Such data prove that the seamless Li/Ag alloying process effectively stabilizes the Li metal anode. However, the voltage polarization of Cu host cycled for 300 h has increased significantly. As has been analyzed above, the Li dendrites on the Cu host consume a large amount of active Li metal and electrolyte, and the dendrites would be easily broken during the cycles to form a large amount of dead Li and dead SEI. Such vicious circles will increase the voltage polarization of Li deposition or stripping, resulting in battery failure.

3D printing technology is conducive to artificial designs of the electrode structures. Based on the research of the 2D Ag host (Ag-0.1 host), 3D printing technology is adopted to construct the 3D Ag host (Figures 5D–5F), which not only increases the specific surface area (Figure S11) but also induces the lateral growth of Li deposition (fill the gaps of the 3D skeletons in Figure 5H). Moreover, the 3D Ag host still maintains alloyed solid-solution state after depositing 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal. According to our COMSOL simulation, the lateral current density of the 3D Ag framework exhibits obvious aggregation, which would be beneficial to the lateral deposition of Li metal, thereby helping alleviate the longitudinal change of the volume (Figure 5G). However, after depositing 1 mAh cm−2 Li metal, although 3D Cu host exhibits lateral growth, the uneven Li deposition induces a large number of dendrites and extra SEI is attached to the surface. Furthermore, too much SEI would consume a large amount of active Li metal and electrolyte, which reduces the CE. As expected, the 3D Ag host exhibits rather uniform Li deposition due to Li/Ag alloying process, and the pores are filled by Li lateral growth due to the 3D structure (Figure S12). What is more, the diffusion coefficient of 3D Ag-0.1 and 3D Cu measured by galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) is around 10−8 cm2 s−1 (Figure S13). Moreover, the diffusion coefficient of the 3D Ag-0.1 host is higher than that of the 3D Cu host, proving that Li/Ag alloying promotes the diffusion of Li ions.

In order to clarify the high reversibility of the 3D host, the coin half-cells were constructed and used to investigate the cyclic stability of the CE at 20°C. Under the condition of 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2 for 300 cycles, 3D Ag host shows the highest average CE of 99.61% among the three hosts (Figure 6A). Ideally, such an average CE can guarantee ∼260 cycles of 1 mAh cm−2 Li metal (because an average of 0.39% Li metal was consumed in each cycle). However, under the condition of 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2 for 100 cycles, the Ag-0.1 host (average CE ∼99.32%) and the 3D Cu host (average CE ∼98.01%) have exhausted 1 mAh cm−2 Li metal after only ∼150 cycles and ∼50 cycles, respectively, due to the high consumption of Li metal. As in the previous analysis, the consumed active Li metal reacts with the electrolyte to form an SEI passivation layer. Such long-term vicious circles would eventually deplete the active Li metal and electrolyte, causing the battery to fail prematurely. Therefore, further research would be needed to improve the average CE, not just the long-cycle stability. Compared with the average CE of the existing hosts, 16
,
45
,
46
,
54
,
56
,
71–75 we have achieved the highest average CE (Figure 6B; Table S1). With an appropriate matching electrolyte, the average CE would be further improved.

With Li foil as the counter electrode or reference electrode and various hosts as the working electrodes, after 50 cycles at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2, a large amount of dead Li remains on both the Cu foil (Figure S14) and the 3D Cu host (Figure 6C). Moreover, the pores of 3D Cu host are almost filled with dead Li, which loses the function of the 3D framework. Although the Ag-0.1 host is still flat, there is accumulation of residual Li on the surface (Figure S14), which is not conducive to subsequent Li deposition or stripping. However, the 3D Ag host retains the original active framework due to its epitaxial Li deposition and high CE (Figure 6D). With LiFePO4 as the cathode and various hosts as the anode, full cells were assembled and tested the charge or discharge cycles at 1C. Obviously, full cells based on LiFePO4 cathode exhibited a capacity retention rate >85% for 500 cycles (Figure 6E), which is due to the highly reversible Li deposition or stripping. Moreover, the cyclic stability of the full cell is better than that of most Li metal batteries (Table S1). In addition, benefiting from the large specific surface area of the 3D structure, the real current density of the 3D Ag host is low, and the rate performance still maintains at a good level (Figure 6F).

To improve the reversibility of Li deposition or stripping, 3D-printed Cu host being coated with a dense nanoscale Ag layer was constructed. The unique structure of 3D Ag induced a lateral growth of Li deposition, which effectively alleviated volume changes and reduced longitudinal stress. Ag was selected, as the Li/Ag alloying process lowered the nucleation overpotential of Li deposition close to zero. The coherent interfacial transition of solid-solution-based Li/Ag alloying process promoted seamless Li deposition. Moreover, the Li/Ag alloying process occurred after the formation of SEI and was not involved in the formation process of SEI so that there was no host interference to the formation of SEI. In addition, the uniform and seamless Li deposition facilitated uniform stress distribution and avoided the formation of multiple SEI, thus indirectly stabilizing the natural SEI, which achieved a highly reversible Li metal anode. Such a 3D Ag host was used as the working electrode to assemble half-cells with Li foil, achieving an average CE ∼99.61% for 300 cycles at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2, which is higher than those of existing Li metal anodes. Full cells based on LiFePO4 cathode exhibited a capacity retention rate >85% for 500 cycles at 1C. The large specific surface area of the 3D structure reduced the effective current density, and hence, the excellent rate performance of full cell was well retained. By precisely regulating host to indirectly stabilize the SEI, the uniform and seamless Li/Ag alloying process provides a strategy for highly reversible Li metal anode.
Further information and requests for resources and reagents should be directed to and will be fulfilled by the lead contact, A/Prof. Bo Wang (wangbo19880804@163.com).

Silver nitrate (AgNO3, >99% Sigma-Aldrich), ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, >99% Sigma-Aldrich), vanillin (C8H8O3, ∼99% Sigma-Aldrich), Li iron phosphate (LiFePO4 [LFP]), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), Super P, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), and Li foil (thickness ∼45 μm) were purchased from S1-LAB PTE. Electrolyte was purchased from Suzhou Duo Chemical Technology. The LFP cathode contains 80 wt % active material, 10 wt % PVDF binder, and 10 wt % Super P coated on an aluminum foil.

Ag foil was constructed by electroless plating. In the plating solution, 3 g L−1 silver nitrate was the main salt and 0.6 vol % ethylenediamine was the complexing agent. In addition, vanillin was used as an additive to regulate uniform silver plating. After the above substances are completely dissolved, a cleaned Cu foil was directly immersed in the plating solution, electroless plating for 60 s, and a uniform Ag layer was plated on the Cu foil. Subsequently, the Ag foil was taken out, washed directly with deionized water, and dried for later use.

3D Ag was constructed by 3D printing technology. Raw material-Cu powder was dissolved in an organic sol, stirred evenly, and then solidified in the refrigerator. Subsequently, the above-mentioned cured product was injected into a spray printing device and the printing pattern was set and printed. Then, the printed 3D Cu was dried naturally to stabilize the 3D Cu framework. In order to remove the organic sol, 3D Cu was calcined and carbonized in a tube furnace to generate pure 3D CuO. Finally, hydrogen annealing was adopted to reduce 3D CuO to pure 3D Cu. Then, combined with the above electroless silver plating (Ag-0.1) process, a uniform Ag-modified layer was constructed on the 3D Cu, and finally, the 3D Ag host was obtained. Moreover, in order to meet the needs of different tests, the thickness of the 3D printing host was two layers, and the diameters are 1.0, 1.2, and 1.4 cm, respectively.

SEM studies were conducted using SEM Zeiss Sigma 300 (10 kV). Moreover, EDX synchronized with SEM facility was adopted to analyze the distribution of Ag and Cu elements on the hosts. XRD spectrum was acquired using Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer machine with Cu Kα as the radiation beam. Surface composition was analyzed by XPS using a Kratos Analytical Axis Ultra DLD UHV spectrometer.

Li electrodeposition curves, CE curves, and CV curves are all tested with half-cells and investigated by 2025-coin cells, using various hosts as the working electrode and commercial Li foil (thickness ∼45 μm) as the counter and reference electrode. Diaphragm type was Celgard 2400 polypropylene porous film. 1 M Li bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) was dissolved in a mixed solvent of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (1:1, v/v) with 2 wt % LiNO3 as the electrolyte (the amount of electrolyte is 50 μL). In addition, the scanning speed of the CV test was 0.1 mV s−1, and the voltage range was −0.1–2.0 V.

Symmetrical batteries are adopted to explore the cyclic stability of the hosts. Based on the above half-cell system, 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal was electrodeposited on various hosts, and the Li-deposited hosts were re-assembled into symmetrical cells. For the full cells, the host deposited with 3 mAh cm−2 Li metal was used as the anode, and the commercial LiFePO4 was used as the cathode to be assembled into 2025-coin cells. For the preparation of the cathode, LiFePO4 (loaded ∼2.3 mg cm−2) was used as the active material, PVDF as the binder, and Super P as conductive agent (mass ratio of 8:1:1), mixed in NMP solvent. Moreover, the charging and discharging range of the full cell was 2.5–4.2 V.

Li+ diffusion coefficient was calculated by GITT based on the equation
D
L i
+
=
4 π
(
n m
V M
S
)
2
(
Δ
E s
Δ
E t
)
2
.
n m and V M are the molar mass (mol) and volume (cm3 mol−1) of the 3D hosts, τ is the time duration of the current pulse, S is surface area of the electrode, ΔE t is the voltage drop during the discharge, and ΔE s is the voltage change during the current pulse. For the 3D electrode, the n m V M = V, so the equation becomes
D
L i
+
=
4
π τ
L 2
(
Δ
E s
Δ
E t
)
2
,
where L is the thickness of the 3D hosts. 52

All models were computed based on DFT with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP), and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) function within the generalized gradient approximation was applied by the exchange-correlation energy. The reasonable vacuum layers were set at around 20 Å in the z direction for avoiding interaction between planes. The cutoff energy and the K point are 450 eV and 3 × 3 × 1, respectively. Geometry optimizations for energy and force were set to 0.02 eV Å−1 and 10−5 eV, respectively. The adsorption energy was defined as follows: ΔE ads = E ads/surf − E ads − E surf , where the E ads/surf , E ads , and E surf are energy of vanillin with Ag/Cu model bound, vanillin, and Ag/Cu model, respectively.

Li+ concentration and electric field distribution at the electrolyte/anode interphase were simulated using COMSOL Multiphysics 5.4 software with the physics module “Secondary Current Distribution.” To simplify the calculation, 3D printing anodes were treated as regular arrayed skeletons from the cross profile. The whole model size was set as 24 × 16 μm, while the diameters of the skeleton and the spacing are 3 and 4 μm, respectively. Cu electrode surface with some protuberances was used as the control group. For all simulation cells, the ionic conductivity of electrolyte was set as 0.01 S m−1 and the applied overpotential of deposition was 100 mV.
